raw_comment:
I notice that there is a legacy boost in elite colleges, meaning that if a parent or sibling goes there you have a much higher chance of getting into that college. I noticed that students who are wealthier, have a greater chance of getting admitted as well. 
I wonder why having a parent or sibling that previously went to that college makes a effect on whether or not a student gets admitted or not, because shouldn’t the college be focusing on you, not others? 
This relates to me and my community, because I am currently a senior making college decisions, and my chances may be lower or higher than other people just based on a family legacy. 
What’s going on in this graph is that it is showing the effects of how legacy and wealth contribute to one’s chance of being admitted into college. A catchy headline would be: If You Have A Legacy, it is Your Legacy To Come To College!
ace_sentences: Some elite colleges give a legacy boost.
A legacy boost means the following.
If a parent of a student attended a college then the student has a higher chance to be admitted to the college.
If a sibling of a student attended a college then the student has a higher chance to be admitted to the college.
Wealthier students have a higher chance to be admitted to a college.
I wonder why a parent or a sibling who attended a college affects the admission of a student.
A college should focus on the student.
A college should not focus on other people.
My chance to be admitted may be lower than the chance of another person because of a family legacy.
My chance to be admitted may be higher than the chance of another person because of a family legacy.
The graph shows the effects of legacy and wealth on the chance of a person to be admitted to a college.
The headline is: If you have a legacy then it is your legacy to come to college.
